title: Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Game Show Host
text:
The Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Game Show Host is an award presented annually by the <a href="National%20Academy%20of%20Television%20Arts%20and%20Sciences">National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences</a> (NATAS) and <a href="Academy%20of%20Television%20Arts%20%26amp%3B%20Sciences">Academy of Television Arts & Sciences</a> (ATAS). It is given to honor the outstanding work of a <a href="game%20show">game show</a> <a href="game%20show%20host">host</a> who has appeared in at least 19% of total episodes for the calendar year.
The <a href="1st%20Daytime%20Emmy%20Awards">1st</a> <a href="Daytime%20Emmy%20Awards">Daytime Emmy Awards</a> ceremony was held in 1974 with <a href="Peter%20Marshall%20%28entertainer%29">Peter Marshall</a> receiving the award for his hosting duty on the <a href="Panel%20game">panel</a> game show "<a href="Hollywood%20Squares">Hollywood Squares</a>". The award category was originally called Outstanding Host or Hostess in a Game or Audience Participation Show before changing to its current title in 1985. The awards ceremony was not aired on television in 1983 and 1984, having been criticized for voting integrity. The Emmy was named after an "Immy", an affectionate term used to refer to the image orthicon camera tube. The statuette was designed by <a href="Louis%20McManus">Louis McManus</a>, who modeled the award after his wife, Dorothy. The Emmy statuette is fifteen inches tall from base to tip, weighing five pounds and is composed of iron, pewter, zinc and gold.
Since its inception, the award has been given to 18 hosts. In 1983, <a href="Betty%20White">Betty White</a> became the first woman to win the award and eventually was joined by <a href="Meredith%20Vieira">Meredith Vieira</a> 22 years later as the only two females to have garnered the award. <a href="Steve%20Harvey">Steve Harvey</a> and <a href="Wayne%20Brady">Wayne Brady</a> are the only African American game show hosts to have won the Emmy. In 1990, <a href="Bob%20Barker">Bob Barker</a> and <a href="Alex%20Trebek">Alex Trebek</a> tied for the award, which was the first tie in this category. Also in 1990, Barker became the host with the most wins in the category when he won a fifth time, surpassing Marshall's previous record of four; Barker went on to win in nine additional years, ultimately receiving fourteen wins. Trebek has since received five additional wins. Trebek also has been nominated on 32 occasions, more than any other host.
As of the <a href="48th%20Daytime%20Emmy%20Awards">2021 ceremony</a>, <a href="Alex%20Trebek">Alex Trebek</a> is the most recent winner in this category for his hosting duty on the game show "<a href="Jeopardy%21">Jeopardy!</a>", winning the award posthumously due to his death in November 2020.
